page.title: Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 33: Line 33:
[[File:Ramy Essam.jpg|thumb|Ramy Essam]]
[[File:Ramy Essam.jpg|thumb|Ramy Essam]]
Ramy Essam, a 23-year-old Egyptian student and musician, was arrest and tortured by the army police on 9 March 2011.<ref name="CNN">{{cite web|author=By Â Reza Sayah, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/17/egypt.activists/index.html |title=Pro-democracy activists allege torture by Egyptian soldiers - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref> He was one of more than 100 people arrested when the army, without warning, stormed the [[Tahrir Square|square]], ripping down tents.<ref name="NPR"/> Essam says men in army uniforms dragged him to the Egyptian National Museum, which had become a security headquarters,<ref name="NPR"/> and took him to a courtyard, stripped him to his shorts, and started torturing him.<ref name="NPR"/> "They used sticks, metal rods, wires, whips." He said he also received electric shocks.<ref name="CNN"/> "There was a soldier who would jump in the air and land on my face with his legs".<ref name="CNN"/> Ramy Essam is best known as "the singer of the Egyptian revolution" due to his popular music during the Egyptian uprising against Hosni Mubarak.<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/03/15/134538629/ramy-esam-the-singer-of-the-egyptian-revolution |title=Ramy Essam: The Singer Of The Egyptian Revolution |publisher=NPR |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref>
Ramy Essam, a 23-year-old Egyptian student and musician, was arrest and tortured by the army police on 9 March 2011.<ref name="CNN">{{cite web|author=By Â Reza Sayah, CNN |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/17/egypt.activists/index.html |title=Pro-democracy activists allege torture by Egyptian soldiers - CNN.com |publisher=Edition.cnn.com |date=18 March 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref> He was one of more than 100 people arrested when the army, without warning, stormed the [[Tahrir Square|square]], ripping down tents.<ref name="NPR"/> Essam says men in army uniforms dragged him to the Egyptian National Museum, which had become a security headquarters,<ref name="NPR"/> and took him to a courtyard, stripped him to his shorts, and started torturing him.<ref name="NPR"/> "They used sticks, metal rods, wires, whips." He said he also received electric shocks.<ref name="CNN"/> "There was a soldier who would jump in the air and land on my face with his legs".<ref name="CNN"/> Ramy Essam is best known as "the singer of the Egyptian revolution" due to his popular music during the Egyptian uprising against Hosni Mubarak.<ref name="NPR">{{cite web|url=http://www.npr.org/2011/03/15/134538629/ramy-esam-the-singer-of-the-egyptian-revolution |title=Ramy Essam: The Singer Of The Egyptian Revolution |publisher=NPR |date=15 March 2011 |accessdate=10 June 2011}}</ref>
â   â
==Murder==
  â
[[File:Coward assault to protesters in Abbaseya Egypt.gif|thumb|Poster for Mohamed Mohsen, another victim of the SCAF, artwork by [[Carlos Latuff]]]]
  â
Ramy Fakhry,<ref name="ahram2"/> a 27-year-old electrical engineer, died as a result of bullet wounds received at an army checkpoint somewhere in the governorate of Damietta. The checkpointâs exact location is unknown.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/crime-a-accidents/family-of-man-killed-at-checkpoint-demands-investigation.html |title=Family of man killed at checkpoint demands investigation |publisher=www.thedailynewsegypt.com|date=2011-05-15 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> According to one, unconfirmed, version of events, Fakhry stopped his car just short of the checkpoint when he saw a gunfight between the army and assailants ahead of him and was shot three times in the back as he attempted to drive away.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1"/> Another version of the story says he left the rig where he worked near Damietta on Friday 13 May to attend a wedding. On his way back later that night at 1 am â before the curfew imposed at the time â Fakhry was shot dead at an army checkpoint.<ref name="ahram2">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/14715/Egypt/Politics-/Activists-and-friends-seek-answers-over-Ramy-Fakhr.aspx |title=Activists and friends seek answers over Ramy Fakhryâs death|publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-06-21 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> A candlelight vigil was organized by Ramy's family and friends on May 14th, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabawy.org/2011/05/17/tribute-to-ramy-fakhry-%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%8A-%D9%81%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%8A/ |title=Tribute to Ramy Fakhry 3|publisher=www.arabawy.org|date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> Head of the Supreme Council for Armed Force (SCAF), Field Marshal Hussein Tantawi, ordered an investigation into the killing of Ramy Fakhry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/people/following-vigil-scaf-orders-investigation-into-army-shooting-of-engineer.html |title=Following vigil, SCAF orders investigation into army shooting of engineer |publisher=www.thedailynewsegypt.com|date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> The statement has not been followed up with any updates concerning the investigation, prompting the call for action.<ref name="ahram2"/> Whatever the circumstances activists believe that Fakhry<ref name="ahram2"/> was killed by the army.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/12289/Egypt/Politics-/Candlelight-vigil-for-Egyptian-shot-by-army-asks-W.aspx |title=Candlelight vigil for Egyptian shot by army asks 'Why was Ramy killed?' |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref>
  â   â
On August 4, Mohamed Mohsen, a protester and an activist, died at Nasser Hospital Institute, 12 days after he was hit with a rock that caused him brain hemorrhage. Mohsen had participated in a march on July 23 heading to the Ministry of Defense in denouncement of SCAF, which was stopped at the neighborhood of Abbasseya by military troops. Thereafter, the entire march was attacked by thugs, and allegedly by the residents of Abbasseya as well, who threw rocks and molotov cocktails at the protesters. One eyewitness said Mohsen was hit by a rock from a nearby rooftop, which made it likely that he was indeed hit by a resident of the area. Protesters were unable to have him hospitalized for over two hours, as ambulances couldn't reach the march, which was surrounded by military police, and he was not taken to the nearby Demerdash Hospital because of rumors that injured protesters were being arrested. After several other hospitals refused to take him in he was eventually admitted at the Nasser Hospital. The lag between his injury and hospitalization as well as apparently very poor health care eventually led to Mohsen's death.<ref>[http://www.shorouknews.com/contentdata.aspx?id=518916 Ululations in farewell to the Abbasseya martyr]</ref> Protesters blamed SCAF for his death, as it was believed the attacks against the march came at the incitement and fear-mongering of the military, and specifically put the blame on Major General Hassan el-Ruweiny. A large funeral was held for him in his home city of [[Aswan]], and around 200 protesters held a funeral at a mosque near [[Tahrir Square]], after [[Friday Prayer]]s. It was blocked from entering the square by military police and [[Central Security Forces]].<ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/483566 Protesters show solidarity with victim of Abbasseya attack]</ref><ref>[http://www.dostor.org/politics/egypt/11/august/5/50278 Military Police block a march to Tahrir Square]</ref><ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/483640 Army and Police close Tahrir Square to Protesters for the first time after the Revolution]</ref> Later during the day, protesters had a Ramadan [[iftar]] in the square in a celebratory manner, but soon afterwards were attacked and dispersed by military police after claiming they were planning on renewing the sit-in in Tahrir.<ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/483685 Army forces disperse the "Tahrir Iftar"]</ref>
 
==Virginity testing==
==Virginity testing==
Line 48: Line 42:
{{Expand section|date=July 2011}}
{{Expand section|date=July 2011}}
Since the overthrow of Mubarak there have been widespread reports of detained Egyptian women having their "virginity checked" by a male officer or doctor. Numerous journalists and released prisoners and protesters have confirmed the practice, by which Egyptian officers were said to evaluate whether or not these women had been raped.<ref>{{cite web|last=Leyne |first=Jon |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13796966 |title=BBC News - Egypt's defiant women fear being cast aside |publisher=Bbc.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=June 2, 2011 |  9:32 am |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/06/egypt-victim-details-virginity-test-denies-military-claims.html |title=EGYPT: Woman denies military's claims about 'virginity test' - latimes.com |publisher=Latimesblogs.latimes.com |date=2011-06-02 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2011/may/31/briefing-page-mideast/ |title=Briefly: Mideast |publisher=Washington Times |date=2011-05-31 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/World/Backchannels/2011/0601/Virginity-tests-Misogyny-and-intimidation-in-Egypt |title=Virginity tests: Misogyny and intimidation in Egypt |publisher=CSMonitor.com |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=NuR8gIYMEY8 |title=âªEgyptian army denies 'virginity tests'â¬â |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/world/0,1518,767365,00.html |title='Horribly Humiliating': Egyptian Woman Tells of 'Virginity Tests' - SPIEGEL ONLINE - News - International |publisher=Spiegel.de |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> The Egyptian military initially denied any virginity checks taking place<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/06/20116255012877754.html |title=Egyptian army denies 'virginity tests' - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-06-02 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> and then asserted the practice would not continue in the future.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20110607/wl_africa_afp/egyptpoliticsunrestrights_20110607172638 |title=Egypt military rulers vow no more virginity tests: HRW - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – Jun 7, 2011 |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h1oml-bY_PJl5W9cPJtbpdUY_y-Q?docId=CNG.fafcacea0287fbeab90256732f165e1e.3a1 |title=AFP: Egypt military rulers vow no more virginity tests: HRW |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-06-07 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> News of the virginity tests sparked a public outcry from [[Amnesty International]] and [[Human Rights Watch]] as well as local Egyptian activists, [[Mona Seif]] for example, and other citizens in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20067419-503543.html |title=Report: Egypt admits to forcing "virginity tests" - World Watch |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10729592 |title=Egyptian activists voice outrage at 'virginity tests' - World - NZ Herald News |publisher=Nzherald.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.cfr.org/coleman/2011/06/03/what-do-egyptians-say-about-the-militarys-virginity-testing/ |title=Isobel Coleman: Democracy in Development Â» Blog Archive Â» What Do Egyptians Say about the Militaryâs âVirginity Testingâ? |publisher=Blogs.cfr.org |date=2011-06-03 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Mackey |first=Robert |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/06/01/egyptian-bloggers-press-army-on-abuses-during-interim-rule/ |title=Egyptian Bloggers Press Army on Abuses During Interim Rule - NYTimes.com |location=Egypt |publisher=Thelede.blogs.nytimes.com |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> Protesters see the tests as evidence that more reform is needed and that the rule under SCAF is neither stable nor trustworthy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/465795 |title=Rights groups says Egypt still needs more change | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/middle-east/disillusion-starts-to-grow-with-egypts-military-amid-fears-of-mini-mubaraks?pageCount=0 |title=Disillusion starts to grow with Egypt's military amid fears of 'mini-Mubaraks - The National |publisher=Thenational.ae |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/466660 |title=Human Rights Watch: The Egyptian revolution is not over | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2010-01-24 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref>
Since the overthrow of Mubarak there have been widespread reports of detained Egyptian women having their "virginity checked" by a male officer or doctor. Numerous journalists and released prisoners and protesters have confirmed the practice, by which Egyptian officers were said to evaluate whether or not these women had been raped.<ref>{{cite web|last=Leyne |first=Jon |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13796966 |title=BBC News - SPIEGEL ONLINE - News - International |publisher=Spiegel.de |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> The Egyptian military initially denied any virginity checks taking place<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/06/20116255012877754.html |title=Egyptian army denies 'virginity tests' - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date=2011-06-02 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> and then asserted the practice would not continue in the future.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://old.news.yahoo.com/s/afp/20110607/wl_africa_afp/egyptpoliticsunrestrights_20110607172638 |title=Egypt military rulers vow no more virginity tests: HRW - Yahoo! News |publisher=News.yahoo.com |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=(AFP) – Jun 7, 2011 |url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5h1oml-bY_PJl5W9cPJtbpdUY_y-Q?docId=CNG.fafcacea0287fbeab90256732f165e1e.3a1 |title=AFP: Egypt military rulers vow no more virginity tests: HRW |publisher=Google.com |date=2011-06-07 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> News of the virginity tests sparked a public outcry from [[Amnesty International]] and [[Human Rights Watch]] as well as local Egyptian activists, [[Mona Seif]] for example, and other citizens in the country.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20067419-503543.html |title=Report: Egypt admits to forcing "virginity tests" - World Watch |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/news/article.cfm?c_id=2&objectid=10729592 |title=Egyptian activists voice outrage at 'virginity tests' - World - NZ Herald News |publisher=Nzherald.co.nz |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.cfr.org/coleman/2011/06/03/what-do-egyptians-say-about-the-militarys-virginity-testing/ |title=Isobel Coleman: Democracy in Development Â» Blog Archive Â» What Do Egyptians Say about the Militaryâs âVirginity Testingâ? |publisher=Blogs.cfr.org |date=2011-06-03 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Mackey |first=Robert |url=http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/06/01/egyptian-bloggers-press-army-on-abuses-during-interim-rule/ |title=Egyptian Bloggers Press Army on Abuses During Interim Rule - NYTimes.com |location=Egypt |publisher=Thelede.blogs.nytimes.com |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref> Protesters see the tests as evidence that more reform is needed and that the rule under SCAF is neither stable nor trustworthy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/465795 |title=Rights groups says Egypt still needs more change | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2011-06-01 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thenational.ae/news/worldwide/middle-east/disillusion-starts-to-grow-with-egypts-military-amid-fears-of-mini-mubaraks?pageCount=0 |title=Disillusion starts to grow with Egypt's military amid fears of 'mini-Mubaraks - The National |publisher=Thenational.ae |date= |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/466660 |title=Human Rights Watch: The Egyptian revolution is not over | Al-Masry Al-Youm: Today's News from Egypt |publisher=Al-Masry Al-Youm |date=2010-01-24 |accessdate=2011-06-20}}</ref>
  +   +
==Murder==
  +
[[File:Coward assault to protesters in Abbaseya Egypt.gif|thumb|Poster for Mohamed Mohsen, another victim of the SCAF, artwork by [[Carlos Latuff]]]]
  +
Ramy Fakhry,<ref name="ahram2"/> a 27-year-old electrical engineer, died as a result of bullet wounds received at an army checkpoint somewhere in the governorate of Damietta. The checkpointâs exact location is unknown.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1">{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/crime-a-accidents/family-of-man-killed-at-checkpoint-demands-investigation.html |title=Family of man killed at checkpoint demands investigation |publisher=www.thedailynewsegypt.com|date=2011-05-15 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> According to one, unconfirmed, version of events, Fakhry stopped his car just short of the checkpoint when he saw a gunfight between the army and assailants ahead of him and was shot three times in the back as he attempted to drive away.<ref name="thedailynewsegypt1"/> Another version of the story says he left the rig where he worked near Damietta on Friday 13 May to attend a wedding. On his way back later that night at 1 am â before the curfew imposed at the time â Fakhry was shot dead at an army checkpoint.<ref name="ahram2">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/14715/Egypt/Politics-/Activists-and-friends-seek-answers-over-Ramy-Fakhr.aspx |title=Activists and friends seek answers over Ramy Fakhryâs death|publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-06-21 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> A candlelight vigil was organized by Ramy's family and friends on May 14th, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabawy.org/2011/05/17/tribute-to-ramy-fakhry-%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%85%D9%8A-%D9%81%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%8A/ |title=Tribute to Ramy Fakhry 3|publisher=www.arabawy.org|date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> Head of the Supreme Council for Armed Force (SCAF), Field Marshal Hussein Tantawi, ordered an investigation into the killing of Ramy Fakhry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/people/following-vigil-scaf-orders-investigation-into-army-shooting-of-engineer.html |title=Following vigil, SCAF orders investigation into army shooting of engineer |publisher=www.thedailynewsegypt.com|date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref> The statement has not been followed up with any updates concerning the investigation, prompting the call for action.<ref name="ahram2"/> Whatever the circumstances activists believe that Fakhry<ref name="ahram2"/> was killed by the army.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/12289/Egypt/Politics-/Candlelight-vigil-for-Egyptian-shot-by-army-asks-W.aspx |title=Candlelight vigil for Egyptian shot by army asks 'Why was Ramy killed?' |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date=2011-05-17 |accessdate=2011-06-30}}</ref>
  +   +
On August 4, Mohamed Mohsen, a protester and an activist, died at Nasser Hospital Institute, 12 days after he was hit with a rock that caused him brain hemorrhage. Mohsen had participated in a march on July 23 heading to the Ministry of Defense in denouncement of SCAF, which was stopped at the neighborhood of Abbasseya by military troops. Thereafter, the entire march was attacked by thugs, and allegedly by the residents of Abbasseya as well, who threw rocks and molotov cocktails at the protesters. One eyewitness said Mohsen was hit by a rock from a nearby rooftop, which made it likely that he was indeed hit by a resident of the area. Protesters were unable to have him hospitalized for over two hours, as ambulances couldn't reach the march, which was surrounded by military police, and he was not taken to the nearby Demerdash Hospital because of rumors that injured protesters were being arrested. After several other hospitals refused to take him in he was eventually admitted at the Nasser Hospital. The lag between his injury and hospitalization as well as apparently very poor health care eventually led to Mohsen's death.<ref>[http://www.shorouknews.com/contentdata.aspx?id=518916 Ululations in farewell to the Abbasseya martyr]</ref> Protesters blamed SCAF for his death, as it was believed the attacks against the march came at the incitement and fear-mongering of the military, and specifically put the blame on Major General Hassan el-Ruweiny. A large funeral was held for him in his home city of [[Aswan]], and around 200 protesters held a funeral at a mosque near [[Tahrir Square]], after [[Friday Prayer]]s. It was blocked from entering the square by military police and [[Central Security Forces]].<ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/node/483566 Protesters show solidarity with victim of Abbasseya attack]</ref><ref>[http://www.dostor.org/politics/egypt/11/august/5/50278 Military Police block a march to Tahrir Square]</ref><ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/483640 Army and Police close Tahrir Square to Protesters for the first time after the Revolution]</ref> Later during the day, protesters had a Ramadan [[iftar]] in the square in a celebratory manner, but soon afterwards were attacked and dispersed by military police after claiming they were planning on renewing the sit-in in Tahrir.<ref>[http://www.almasryalyoum.com/node/483685 Army forces disperse the "Tahrir Iftar"]</ref>
==See also==
==See also==
